I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Over the past decade, the National People’s Congress (NPC) of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance on five occasions on 
behalf  of  its  special  committee  charged  with  responsibility  for  overseeing  environmental 
legislation.    That  committee  is  now  known  as  the  Environment  Protection  and  Resources 
Conservation  Committee  (EPRCC).    Following  a  request  by  EPRCC  for  further  technical 
assistance (TA) to be rendered during the Government’s current Five-Year Legislative Program 
(2003-2008), a fact-finding mission visited the PRC in February 2004.  The proposed TA was 
included in the country strategy and program update (2004–2006) for the PRC.1  The scope of 
the assistance was further refined during the course of the year, most recently during a further 
visit to the PRC in October 2004.  This report is based on the understandings reached with the 
Government and EPRCC on the objectives, scope, costs and implementation arrangements for 
the TA. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.2 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Biodiversity provides the basis for the survival of human societies and for their economic 
and social development. The best way to safeguard biodiversity is through nature reserves and 
similar protected areas.  The PRC’s government has shown its commitment to the conservation 
of the country’s ecological environment by steadily increasing the number of nature reserves 
countrywide, particularly since the beginning of the 1990s following ratification by the PRC of 
the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). 3 
3.  The PRC ranks in the world's top three countries for biodiversity and it has a higher 
proportion of the world’s endemic species than any other country. It is home to 30,000 species 
of seed plants, 6,300 species of vertebrates, and 3,862 species of fish.4 Chinese plant species 
are estimated to represent over 11% of the world’s total, among which over 240 species or 
genera are endemic to the PRC. The reptile, bird, mammal and amphibian species in the PRC 
account  for  over  10%  of  the  world’s  total.    Despite  this  richness,  however,  the  PRC’s 
environment has suffered severe damage in recent years because of rapid population growth, 
unsustainable exploitation of resources, environmental pollution, and ecosystem destruction.  All 
of this has resulted in great loss to the PRC’s biodiversity. To meet the threats to its biological 
resources, by the end of 2003 the PRC had established 1,999 nature reserves covering more 
than 14,000 square kilometers (km2) and accounting for about 14% of its territory.   Most of 
these reserves have been established in the past 10 years.

4.  The PRC’s legislative framework for nature reserves and protected areas has not kept 
pace with these developments. The responsibility for administering these various protected 
habitats rests with at least six different government departments or agencies.5  A number of 
different regulations and other management measures are in place,6 but there is no overarching 
law.  The underdeveloped nature of the legislative framework has now been recognized by the 
Government, leading to NPC being designated as the body responsible for overseeing the 
drafting of a new nature reserve law.  Since early 2003, EPRCC has been commissioning in-
depth studies of how existing regulations are being applied from within the Government - e.g. 
from  the  State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  (SEPA)  and  the  State  Forestry 
Administration (SFA) - and also from nongovernment organizations such as the South-North 
Institute for Sustainable Development.  It is expected that these reports will be completed no 
later than June 2005.  One of the tasks of the consultants under this TA will be to assist EPRCC 
in its consideration of the findings and recommendations of these reports and to provide case 
studies of different approaches to this area of the law in other jurisdictions.  EPRCC is due to 
submit its proposed draft of a new nature reserve law to NPC no later than mid-2006.   
5.  Soil degradation, which is closely related to biodiversity loss, now threatens not simply 
biodiversity but the quality of life generally for the PRC's 1.3 billion people. The PRC now has 
many of the worst soil degradation problems in the world, with over 40% of its land area, or 
between 3-4 million km2, adversely affected.7  Recent reports from the Chinese Academy of 
Sciences indicate that trends in soil degradation caused by wind erosion, salinization, and 
desertification are increasing.  The rate of expansion has risen from around 1,500 km2 per year 
in the 1950s to approaching 3,500 km2 per year in the late 1990s. Annual soil loss is estimated 
to be 5 billion tons. There is growing recognition worldwide that a sound legal and institutional 
framework for managing soils is critical for the conservation of biological diversity as well as for 
food production and poverty alleviation.   
6.  Various important global environmental strategies have been developed in recent years.8 
One of these, UNEP’s Montevideo Programme III (The Programme for the Development and 
Periodic Review of Environmental Law for the first Decade of the Twenty-First Century)9 was 
finalized in 2001, and emphasizes the implementation of environmental law.  Under its objective 
for soils (objective 12), it proposes two actions: first, a review of domestic land use laws, and 
changes to land use laws and tenure systems to achieve soil conservation and reclamation 
goals; and second, promotion of the integration of soil conservation measures into relevant

3
domestic laws, taking into account relevant international treaties such as the United Nations 
Convention to Combat Desertification. What is being called for, in other words, is a general 
initiative  for  soil  legislation  reform,  including  undertaking  actions  such  as  improving  the 
effectiveness of environmental law on soils, improving the conservation and management of 
soil,  and  forging  better  links  between  environmental  law  on  soils  and  other  fields  of 
environmental law.10 
7.  The PRC Government recognizes that combating soil degradation needs to be made a 
national development priority. Its commitment to sustainable natural resource management is 
reflected in the Tenth Five-Year Plan, 2001–2005 which, among other things, calls for increased 
protection for land, forests, and grassland.  An overarching, holistic soil protection law has not 
yet been included in the Government’s national legislative program11, but work has been started 
at the provincial level and it is probably only a matter of time before a national legal and 
institutional framework for managing soils is placed on the legislative agenda12. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
8.  The TA will provide assistance covering the two possible laws on (i) nature reserve 
zones, and (ii) soil protection. 
1.  Nature Reserve Zone Law 
9.  The PRC has now set up about 2,000 nature reserves, of which around 200 are national 
reserves. Together they cover about 14% of the PRC’s total land area. The establishment and 
management of these nature reserves is currently governed primarily by regulations adopted by 
the State Council in 1994. EPRCC has been designated by NPC as the agency responsible for 
drafting a law to govern nature reserve zones and is scheduled begin this task in early 2005 and 
complete it by mid-2006. A symposium to consider the findings and recommendations of the 
consultants will be held towards the end of the law drafting process, probably in the first quarter 
of 2006. 
10.  Under the TA, a firm will be engaged to provide the international consultants to advise 
EPRCC in connection with the review and drafting process. For the purpose of this TA, the term 
“firm” will be interpreted broadly, and could include a nongovernment organization, a university, 
or a scientific or environmental institution. The chosen firm will be responsible for engaging a 
team of local consultants to assist. 
                                                
10   See also Hannam, Ian, and Ben Boer. 2004. Drafting Legislation for Sustainable Soils: A Guide.  IUCN 
Environmental Policy and Law Paper No. 52,  page 14. IUCN. 
11   There exists a national law directly related to soil, the Water and Soil Conservation Law (1991).  However, this 
law does not cover all issues on soils, in particular the prevention or abatement of soil degradation resulting from 
agricultural and industrial activities. 
12   The ADB is currently working closely with the Global Environment Facility (GEF) on the China-GEF Partnership 
on Land Degradation in Dryland Ecosystems which has the goal of promoting sustainable development in the 
PRC’s western region.  The ADB is also providing TA for a number of local initiatives in the PRC’s north east: 
ADB. 2003. Songhua River Water Quality and Pollution Control Management. Manila.  Under the TA to support 
Transjurisdictional  Environment  Management  (see  footnote  2(v)  above),  the  ADB  is  also  assisting  the 
Government in the development of relevant legislation.

4    
11.  The international consultants will also work with EPRCC in designing a study tour to one 
selected country. The goal of the trip will be to visit government officials, academic institutions 
and NGOs so as to reach a better understanding of international legislative trends and key 
issues in nature reserve management.   
12.  In addition to the final symposium, the international consultants may also be requested 
to  organize  one  or  more  workshops  to  provide  forums  for  the review of the findings and 
recommendations of the ongoing studies commissioned by EPRCC.  The extent and timing of 
such workshops will depend upon the output of those ongoing studies and on the issues raised.  
Provision has been made under the TA to engage resource persons to participate in such 
workshops should they be required. 
13.  The international consultants (four or five persons) should be experts on nature reserves 
generally, nature reserve management, and nature reserve law. The domestic consultants (up 
to eight persons) should be experts in the fields of nature reserve zone law, environmental law, 
nature reserve zone management, and nature reserves generally. 
2.  Legislative Proposals for Sustainable Soils 
14.  At this stage, EPRCC’s expectations are that only a feasibility study will be required of 
the consultant(s) engaged under this part of the TA, although the study will contain a suggested 
form or forms of draft legislation. The consultants may be engaged either as individuals or as a 
firm. The scope of this part of the TA will be reviewed during the period of the TA, with final 
decisions regarding scope and timing being dependent partly on EPRCC’s work program, and 
partly on whether any savings have been realized under the earlier parts of the TA.  The bulk of 
the work under this part of the TA is likely to be completed in 2006. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will assist the government agency responsible for developing key environment 
legislation by exposing it to best international practice. 
16.  The TA will provide support to the legislative process through the following inputs: 
(i)  a  comprehensive  review  and  assessment  of  the  existing  legislative 
framework dealing with environmental protection, in particular as it touches 
upon nature reserve zones and protection of the soil; and 
(ii)  advice on the establishment of a more modern framework for legislation 
concerning nature reserves and sustainable soils; formulation of legislative 
plans and procedures affecting these areas in particular, and possibly others 
as required; preparation of draft laws as case studies; a comparative study on 
international best practices in these and related areas. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, of which $243,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $257,000 equivalent is the local currency cost.  The Government has 
requested that ADB finance $400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$157,000 equivalent of the local currency cost.  The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant 
basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will

5
finance the balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $100,000, through the provision of 
counterpart  staff,  office  accommodation,  conference  venues,  local  transportation,  local 
communications, interpretation and translation services, the administration for workshops and 
symposiums and other miscellaneous administration expenses.  Detailed cost estimates and the 
financing plan are shown in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be EPRCC.  Management of the TA is expected to 
be assisted by a part–time consultant to be engaged by ADB under a separate budget. It is 
intended that this part–time consultant, who will have a permanent office at the ADB resident 
mission, will liaise regularly with EPRCC staff to ensure smooth and rapid implementation of the 
TA.  This individual will also oversee the establishment and operation of any advance payment 
facility created in support of the program of workshops and symposiums. 
19.  It is also expected that EPRCC will liaise, and will require the consultants to liaise, with 
all  affected  parties.  These  will  include,  but  will  not  necessarily  be  limited  to,  the  National 
Development and Reform Commission, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of 
Water  Resources,  Ministry  of  Land  and  Resources,  State  Environmental  Protection 
Administration,  Chinese  Academy  of  Sciences,  State  Forestry  Administration,  Ministry  of 
Science  and  Technology,  the  South-North  Institute  for  Sustainable  Development,  NPC’s 
Legislative Work Committee, and the Legislative Affairs Office of the State Council. 
20.  Services  of  both  international  and  domestic  consultants  will  be  required  and  also 
resource persons where appropriate.   Details of the services to be provided by the consultants 
are in Appendix 3. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to the ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. The implementation of the TA is expected to begin in May 
2005 and to be completed by November 2006. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Support for Environmental Legislation, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS  
AND TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
AND RESOURCE PERSONS 
 
1.  To carry out the technical assistance (TA), consultants will be engaged by the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), either as individuals or as a firm,13 to assist the Environmental 
Protection  and  Resources  Conservation  Committee  (EPRCC)  of  the  National  People’s 
Congress (NPC).  
2.  As part of the current legislative program of the People’s Republic of China (PRC),  
EPRCC is required to have a draft nature reserve zone law ready by mid-2006, and a feasibility 
study on a possible soil protection law by the end of 2006. Separate teams of consultants will be 
engaged to assist with work related to each law. 
A.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Nature Reserve Zone Law   
3.  Implementation of this part of the TA will take place in three phases. 
(i)  Phase I. Three consultants (one international and two domestic) will carry 
out  a  general  background  study  to  complement  more  in-depth  but 
narrower  studies  being  carried  out  by  various  government  and 
government-related agencies. The international consultant, who will act 
as team leader throughout all three phases, will supply an overview of 
international experience and best practice in this area. The two domestic 
consultants  will  provide  background  studies  on  (i)  the  present  legal 
infrastructure, and (ii) the actual administration of nature reserve zones 
and protected areas throughout the PRC. The three individual reports 
resulting from phase I will identify main issues and problems. Phase I will 
be completed within 2 months. 
(ii)  Phase II. The international consultant will head a team of up to eight 
domestic consultants and resource persons in carrying out studies in 
specific areas highlighted in phase I. The international consultant will 
develop case studies from a representative sampling of foreign countries 
identified at the completion of phase I, and analyze key issues to be 
covered in any legislative framework.  The domestic consultants will each 
complete a separate study on their area of specialization. Phase II is 
expected to last three months.  
(iii)  Phase III. The consultants will prepare a final report by November 2005. 
This will include recommendations on the legal framework. The report 
and draft law will be the subject of an international symposium in early 
2006. 
                                                
13   The term “firm” could include a nongovernment organization, an academic institution or similar.

Appendix 3  11 
The international consultant should be a lawyer with experience in law drafting and 
policy formulation, and also with experience in the establishment and management of 
nature reserves or equivalent. The domestic consultants are expected to be made up of 
a  combination  of  legal  experts,  management  experts  and  technical  experts.      The 
consultants should also be qualified to conduct workshops and recruit resource persons 
throughout this three-phase process.  The scope and size of these workshops will be 
decided during the course of the TA. 
2.   Legislative Proposals for Sustainable Soils  
4.  The implementation of this part of the TA will involve a single phase. Three consultants 
(one international and two domestic) will undertake a feasibility study on how the PRC might 
develop a future legislative framework to address issues of soil degradation.  
5.  Once completed, the study would be provided as a report to all EPRCC congressmen. If 
desired,  a  workshop  to  discuss  the  report’s  recommendations  could  be  organized  to 
disseminate the report to a wider audience.  
B.  Terms of Reference 
1.  Nature Reserve Zone Law 
a.  International Consultants (total of 5.5 person-months) 
6.  During phase I, the consultants will perform the following tasks.  
(i)  Carry out comparative studies, and individually review general legal frameworks 
relating to nature reserve zone management in a representative sampling of 
other  countries.  These  studies  will  analyze  experience  in  legislation  and 
management  of  nature  reserve  zones  in  these  countries,  and  recommend 
suitable legal frameworks for nature reserve zone conservation in the PRC.  
(ii)  In consultation with domestic consultants, prepare terms of reference for the 
domestic consultants to be engaged under phase II. 
(iii)  Design a study tour to enable key staff involved in the formulation of the new law 
to  visit  one  country  for  consultations  with  all  relevant  groups  including 
government officials, legal drafters, NGOs and local communities. 
7.  During phase II, the consultants will perform the following tasks. 
(i)  Provide an in-depth study of best practice on successful nature reserve zone 
management  in  selected  countries,  and  evaluate  what  practices  are  most 
applicable to the PRC.  Based on this study, they will recommend how to improve 
nature reserve zone management in the PRC.  
(ii)  Oversee  the  work  of  the  domestic  consultants  in  preparing  their  individual 
reports.

12  Appendix 3 
8.  During phase III, the consultants will perform the following tasks. 
(i)  Recommend and draft appropriate legislation.  
(ii)  Organize an international symposium. 
b.  Domestic Consultants (total of 30 person-months) 
9.  During phase I, two domestic consultants will undertake a background study of the way 
nature reserve zones are currently established and managed in the PRC. In the course of this 
study, they will review existing laws, regulations and policies affecting nature reserve zones. 
They will examine the implementation of such laws, regulations and policies, and evaluate how 
successful such policies and regulations have been to date. Working with the international 
consultant,  they  will  identify  key  legal  issues  of  nature  reserve  zone  management  and 
conservation in the PRC.  These issues will be studied in further depth under phase II.  
10.  It is anticipated that phase II consultants will address such issues as: 
(i)  nature reserve zone planning, 
 (ii)  management systems and key instruments and mechanisms for administering 
nature reserves and protected areas, 
 (iii)  land ownership and tenure issues, 
 (iv)  public participation, 
(v)  categorization of nature reserves, and 
(vi)  financial mechanisms for funding nature reserves and protected areas. 
11.  Under phase III, selected consultants from phases I and II will assist the international 
consultant  in  the  drafting  of  recommended  legislation  for  discussion  at  an  international 
symposium. 
2.  Legislative Proposals for Sustainable Soils  
a.  International Consultants (total of 1.5 person-months) and Domestic 
Consultants (total of 4 person-months) 
12.  The output of this part of the TA will be a feasibility study carried out by one or more 
international consultants ( lawyers specializing in the drafting of legislation for sustainable soils), 
with the assistance of two domestic consultants (one to research and collate all existing national 
and provincial legislation and related legal instruments, and the other to assist with report writing 
and legal drafting). 
13.  The report resulting from this feasibility study should do the following, among other 
things.  
(i)  Include an assessment of all laws and regulations currently in place in the PRC 
that  address  the  issue  of  soil  pollution,  including  addressing  the  issue  of 
enforcement of existing laws.

Appendix 3  13 
(ii)  Include  a  summary  and  brief  assessment  of  the  various  initiatives  already 
underway at the provincial level addressing the issue of soil pollution. 
(iii)  Provide  a  general  overview  of  all  current  international  legal  and  institutional 
regimes   for soil. It should highlight the strategies and processes behind present 
efforts  to  promote  an  international  legal  framework  to  protect  the  soil 
environment. It should summarize those international instruments, both binding 
and nonbinding, that are directed at improving the conservation, rehabilitation 
and sustainable use of soils at global or regional levels. 
(iv)  Provide a representative overview of different national legal strategies for soil, 
including  a  review  of  existing  national  soil  legislation  frameworks,  and  the 
elements needed for effective national soil legislation. It should highlight those 
national legal strategies that to date have been most successful in enabling 
individual nations to make sound land use and land management decisions, and 
in building capacity to communicate these strategies. 
(iv)  Recommend which national legislative framework is most suitable for the PRC, 
and offer samples of appropriate legislation to establish such a framework at the 
national level.
